<https://analyticgarden.blogspot.com/2018/03/julia-and-blockchain.html?m=1|https://analyticgarden.blogspot.com/2018/03/julia-and-blockchain.html?m=1>

messages.text: I don't know about your strategy of building up a blockchain by accrual.  Starting small is fine, still -- you should have a sense of where you are going before you begin.  Perhaps you do.

elements.text: I don't know about your strategy of building up a blockchain by accrual.  Starting small is fine, still -- you should have a sense of where you are going before you begin.  Perhaps you do.

messages.text: <@UR9TWADMF> I'm as big a diehard fan of Julia, but I would emphatically recommend you check out using other languages for the implementation. Probably Rust.

elements.text: I'm as big a diehard fan of Julia, but I would emphatically recommend you check out using other languages for the implementation. Probably Rust.

messages.text: Julia is great - but the cryptography and safety critical ecosystem in Julia is not anywhere near as mature as you would need if you were to earnestly going to start developing blockchains in Julia and putting in millions of other people's money on it.

elements.text: Julia is great - but the cryptography and safety critical ecosystem in Julia is not anywhere near as mature as you would need if you were to earnestly going to start developing blockchains in Julia and putting in millions of other people's money on it.

attachments.title: Blockchain
attachments.text: Where i see Julia adding immediate value is as a higher level language used to generate the evm, michelson and all the other craziness that’s out there. Similar to the idea of emitting web assembly. No need to re-invent the wheel in terms of new cryptographic packages. All that’s needed is a way to write smart contracts in Julia and have the deployment and compilation handled by the native tech. In terms of other relevant cryptos that will likely succeed. EOS (which promises the moon) seems li...
